subject: history
title: Key Revolutionaries (1908-1917) - Comparative Analysis
description: Detailed comparison of major revolutionary leaders and their contributions

rows.name: üî• KHUDIRAM BOSE
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Youngest revolutionary martyr (18 years)
‚Ä¢ Attempted assassination of Magistrate Kingsford
‚Ä¢ Symbol of youthful sacrifice
‚Ä¢ Inspired entire generation
rows.incident:
Muzaffarpur Bomb Case (April 30, 1908)

‚Ä¢ Target: Magistrate Kingsford
‚Ä¢ Bomb killed two British ladies by mistake
‚Ä¢ Partner Prafulla Chaki committed suicide
‚Ä¢ Khudiram caught, showed no remorse
rows.fate:
Hanged: August 11, 1908 (aged 18)

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Became instant folk hero
‚Ä¢ Songs written about him
‚Ä¢ 'Khudiram Bose Balidan Diwas'
‚Ä¢ Inspired youth across India
‚Ä¢ Youngest martyr of revolution

rows.name: üïâÔ∏è AUROBINDO GHOSH
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Intellectual leader of revolutionary movement
‚Ä¢ Editor of revolutionary newspaper Jugantar
‚Ä¢ Advocated complete independence
‚Ä¢ Wrote revolutionary articles
‚Ä¢ Inspired youth through writings
‚Ä¢ Later became spiritual leader
rows.incident:
Alipore Bomb Conspiracy Case (1908-09)

‚Ä¢ Chief accused (34 total)
‚Ä¢ British wanted to convict him as mastermind
‚Ä¢ Defended brilliantly by C.R. Das
‚Ä¢ Gave no evidence; maintained silence
‚Ä¢ Approver Naren Goswami failed to implicate him convincingly
rows.fate:
Acquitted: May 1909

After:
‚Ä¢ Left politics (1910)
‚Ä¢ Went to Pondicherry
‚Ä¢ Became spiritual guru
‚Ä¢ Founded Sri Aurobindo Ashram
‚Ä¢ Shifted from revolutionary to spiritual nationalism

rows.name: ‚öîÔ∏è BARINDRA KUMAR GHOSH
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Aurobindo's younger brother
‚Ä¢ Founded Jugantar newspaper
‚Ä¢ Ran bomb-making factory at Maniktala Garden
‚Ä¢ Trained revolutionaries
‚Ä¢ Active organizer and operative leader
rows.incident:
Alipore Bomb Conspiracy Case

‚Ä¢ Main operative accused
‚Ä¢ Evidence found at Maniktala bomb factory
‚Ä¢ Convicted as mastermind of operations
‚Ä¢ Sentenced to death initially
rows.fate:
Death sentence commuted to life

Transported to Andaman

Released: 1920

After:
‚Ä¢ Gave up revolutionary path
‚Ä¢ Became writer and journalist
‚Ä¢ Wrote books on nationalism

rows.name: üí™ MADAN LAL DHINGRA
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Took revolutionary violence to Britain
‚Ä¢ Member of India House, London
‚Ä¢ Inspired by Savarkar
‚Ä¢ Showed Indians willing to die for freedom
‚Ä¢ Defiant till end
rows.incident:
Murder of Curzon Wyllie (July 1, 1909)

‚Ä¢ Location: Imperial Institute Hall, London
‚Ä¢ Shot Sir William Curzon Wyllie (5 bullets)
‚Ä¢ Also killed Dr. Cawas Lalcaca
‚Ä¢ Made no attempt to escape
‚Ä¢ Refused to apologize in court
rows.fate:
Hanged: August 17, 1909 (Pentonville Prison, London)

Famous Statement:
‚Ä¢ 'I believe only lesson required in India is to learn to die'
‚Ä¢ 'I am proud to die for my country'

Legacy: Martyr who shocked British establishment

rows.name: üìö VINAYAK DAMODAR SAVARKAR
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Most influential revolutionary ideologue
‚Ä¢ Founded Abhinav Bharat (1904)
‚Ä¢ Wrote 'The Indian War of Independence, 1857'
‚Ä¢ Trained revolutionaries in London (India House)
‚Ä¢ Openly advocated armed revolution
‚Ä¢ Hindu nationalist ideology
rows.incident:
Nashik Conspiracy Case (1910)

‚Ä¢ Implicated in Jackson's murder
‚Ä¢ Arrested in London (March 1910)
‚Ä¢ Attempted dramatic escape in Marseilles
‚Ä¢ Swam to French shore but recaptured
‚Ä¢ International legal controversy
rows.fate:
Sentenced: Two life terms (50 years total)

Transported to Andaman Cellular Jail (Kalapani)

Released: 1921 (with restrictions till 1937)

Later:
‚Ä¢ Became Hindu nationalist leader
‚Ä¢ Founded Hindu Mahasabha ideology
‚Ä¢ Controversial mercy petitions
‚Ä¢ Key figure in Hindu nationalism

rows.name: üéØ ANANT LAXMAN KANHERE
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Young revolutionary inspired by Savarkar
‚Ä¢ Student revolutionary
‚Ä¢ Willing to sacrifice life
‚Ä¢ Acted alone without escape plan
rows.incident:
Murder of Collector Jackson (Dec 21, 1909)

‚Ä¢ Location: Theatre in Nasik during play
‚Ä¢ Shot Collector Jackson who was harsh on Indians
‚Ä¢ Point-blank range, no escape attempt
‚Ä¢ Calmly surrendered
rows.fate:
Hanged: April 19, 1910 (aged 19)

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Martyr of Maharashtra revolutionary movement
‚Ä¢ His action led to Savarkar's arrest
‚Ä¢ Remembered for fearless sacrifice

rows.name: üéñÔ∏è RASH BEHARI BOSE
rows.region:
Bengal ‚Üí All India

Anushilan Samiti, Ghadar links
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Master conspirator and organizer
‚Ä¢ Planned Delhi Conspiracy (1912)
‚Ä¢ Coordinated Ghadar Uprising (1915)
‚Ä¢ Escaped British for years
‚Ä¢ Later founded INA in Japan
rows.incident:
Delhi Conspiracy (Dec 23, 1912)

‚Ä¢ Bomb on Viceroy Hardinge's procession
‚Ä¢ Planned during Delhi Durbar
‚Ä¢ Viceroy seriously injured
‚Ä¢ Basanta Kumar Biswas threw bomb, caught
‚Ä¢ RB Bose escaped despite massive manhunt
rows.fate:
Escaped to Japan (1915)

Lived in Japan till death (1945)

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Founded Indian Independence League
‚Ä¢ Organized INA in Japan
‚Ä¢ Handed INA to Subhash Bose (1943)
‚Ä¢ Bridge between revolutionary and INA movement

rows.name: üí• BASANTA KUMAR BISWAS
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Executed Delhi Conspiracy
‚Ä¢ Brave operative who didn't betray colleagues
‚Ä¢ Maintained silence during torture
rows.incident:
Delhi Conspiracy (Dec 23, 1912)

‚Ä¢ Threw bomb at Viceroy Hardinge
‚Ä¢ Attendant killed, Viceroy injured
‚Ä¢ Arrested after long hunt
‚Ä¢ Refused to name Rash Behari Bose despite torture
rows.fate:
Hanged: May 1915

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Loyal revolutionary who protected colleagues
‚Ä¢ Suffered silently

rows.name: üåç LALA HAR DAYAL
rows.region:
Punjab ‚Üí USA, Germany

Ghadar Party (Founder)
Berlin Committee
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Brilliant intellectual (Oxford scholar)
‚Ä¢ Founded Ghadar Party (1913)
‚Ä¢ Published 'Ghadar' newspaper
‚Ä¢ Mobilized Indian diaspora in USA
‚Ä¢ Sought international support for revolution
‚Ä¢ Socialist ideology
rows.incident:
Ghadar Movement (1913-1915)

‚Ä¢ Organized Ghadarites' return to India
‚Ä¢ Coordinated with revolutionaries in India
‚Ä¢ WWI seen as opportunity
‚Ä¢ US government arrested him (1914)
‚Ä¢ Escaped to Berlin, joined Berlin Committee
rows.fate:
Escaped USA, went to Germany

Worked with Berlin Committee

Died: 1939, Philadelphia

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ International face of Indian revolution
‚Ä¢ Connected overseas Indians to freedom struggle
‚Ä¢ Intellectual revolutionary

rows.name: üöú SOHAN SINGH BHAKNA
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ First President of Ghadar Party
‚Ä¢ Represented farmer-worker base
‚Ä¢ Mobilized Punjabi immigrants
‚Ä¢ Socialist leanings
‚Ä¢ Worked for farmers' rights
rows.incident:
Ghadar Movement

‚Ä¢ Led organizational efforts
‚Ä¢ Returned to India with Ghadarites (1914)
‚Ä¢ Arrested in Punjab
rows.fate:
Imprisoned in Lahore Conspiracy Case

Released: 1930

After:
‚Ä¢ Joined left-wing movement
‚Ä¢ Worked for peasants and workers
‚Ä¢ Communist inclinations

Died: 1968

Legacy: Represented working-class revolutionary

rows.name: üî• KARTAR SINGH SARABHA
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Youngest Ghadar martyr (19 years)
‚Ä¢ Brilliant organizer and writer
‚Ä¢ Wrote for Ghadar newspaper
‚Ä¢ Inspired by 1857 Revolt
‚Ä¢ Returned to India for uprising
rows.incident:
Ghadar Uprising Attempt (1915)

‚Ä¢ Returned from USA (1914)
‚Ä¢ Worked to incite mutiny in Punjab regiments
‚Ä¢ Arrested before uprising
‚Ä¢ Tried in Lahore Conspiracy Case
rows.fate:
Hanged: November 16, 1915 (aged 19)

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Icon of Ghadar Movement
‚Ä¢ Bhagat Singh's idol (inspired him)
‚Ä¢ Youngest Ghadar martyr
‚Ä¢ Symbol of youth sacrifice

rows.name: ‚ò™Ô∏è MAULANA MAHMUD HASAN
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Senior Islamic scholar involved in revolution
‚Ä¢ Sought Turkish Caliphate support
‚Ä¢ Planned Provisional Government at Kabul
‚Ä¢ Represented Muslim participation in revolution
‚Ä¢ Shaikhul Hind title
rows.incident:
Silk Letter Conspiracy (1915-1916)

‚Ä¢ Planned Provisional Government (Kabul, 1915)
‚Ä¢ Leaders: Obaidullah Sindhi, Raja Mahendra Pratap
‚Ä¢ Sought Afghan-Turkish invasion of India
‚Ä¢ Messages on silk cloth
‚Ä¢ British intercepted letters
rows.fate:
Arrested in Mecca (1916)

Imprisoned in Malta (1916-1920)

Released: 1920 (health broken)

Died: 1920

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Showed Muslim ulema's anti-British stance
‚Ä¢ Influenced Ali Brothers and Khilafat leaders

rows.name: üá©üá™ VIRENDRANATH CHATTOPADHYAYA
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Sarojini Naidu's brother
‚Ä¢ Led Berlin Committee during WWI
‚Ä¢ Sought German support for revolution
‚Ä¢ Coordinated international revolutionary efforts
‚Ä¢ Communist ideology
rows.incident:
Hindu-German Conspiracy (1914-1917)

‚Ä¢ Berlin Committee coordinated with Ghadar Party
‚Ä¢ Planned arms shipments to India
‚Ä¢ Worked with German government
‚Ä¢ Most plans failed
‚Ä¢ Continued revolutionary work from Europe
rows.fate:
Remained in Europe

Joined Communist International

Disappeared in Stalin's purges (1937)

Presumably executed in Soviet Union

Legacy: International revolutionary; tragic end

rows.name: üìñ BHUPENDRANATH DUTTA
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Swami Vivekananda's younger brother
‚Ä¢ Revolutionary and socialist thinker
‚Ä¢ Wrote for Jugantar newspaper
‚Ä¢ Member of Berlin Committee
‚Ä¢ Historian and scholar of socialism
rows.incident:
Multiple revolutionary activities

‚Ä¢ Arrested in Barisal Conspiracy Case
‚Ä¢ Imprisoned several times
‚Ä¢ Worked with Berlin Committee during WWI
‚Ä¢ Continued revolutionary work from Europe
rows.fate:
Imprisoned multiple times

After:
‚Ä¢ Became Marxist scholar
‚Ä¢ Wrote extensively on Indian history and socialism
‚Ä¢ Joined Communist movement

Died: 1961

Legacy: Revolutionary who became intellectual

rows.name: üêÖ JATINDRANATH MUKHERJEE (BAGHA JATIN)
rows.contribution:
‚Ä¢ Called 'Bagha Jatin' (Tiger Jatin) for killing tiger bare-handed
‚Ä¢ Master organizer
‚Ä¢ Coordinated with Ghadar and German support
‚Ä¢ Planned armed uprising during WWI
‚Ä¢ Established revolutionary network
rows.incident:
Balasore Conspiracy (September 1915)

‚Ä¢ Waiting for German arms shipment (never arrived)
‚Ä¢ Engaged in gun battle with British police at Balasore, Odisha
‚Ä¢ Fought bravely despite being outnumbered
‚Ä¢ Seriously wounded in firefight
rows.fate:
Died: September 10, 1915 (from injuries)

Legacy:
‚Ä¢ Legendary revolutionary hero
‚Ä¢ Combined physical prowess with organizational skills
‚Ä¢ 'Bagha Jatin' became synonym for bravery

additionalInfo.title: Comparative Analysis

patterns.detail: Mostly young (18-30 years); Khudiram (18), Sarabha (19), Kanhere (19) were teenagers
Highly educated elite; many had college education or studied abroad
Bengal most active, followed by Maharashtra and Punjab; some went international
Mix of nationalism, socialism, and religious revivalism; all wanted complete independence
Assassinations, bomb attacks, armed dacoities; secret societies and underground networks
Many hanged as martyrs; some imprisoned in Andaman; few escaped abroad; movement crushed by 1917
Inspired next generation (Bhagat Singh, Chandrasekhar Azad); showed inadequacy of terrorism; many later revolutionaries joined Gandhi

additionalInfo.examTip: Remember the trio for each region: Bengal (Khudiram, Aurobindo, RB Bose), Maharashtra (Savarkar, Kanhere), Punjab (Har Dayal, Bhakna, Sarabha)
